div.div: How to prepare DITA content for localization
Chapter . Writing with localization in mind
Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.
Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.
Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.
Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.
Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.

xml:lang and
translate attributes.

Learn how to adjust text sorting using the
sort-as and
index-sort-as elements and change text direction using the
dir element.
Learn about best practices of reusing content with conrefs and keyrefs to avoid problems with localization.
Learn how to quickly replace content references and key references with content in oXygen XML Editor.

Learn how to import your DITA project into
while preserving the project's folder structure.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.

section.div:
A text that is easy to understand is usually also easier to translate. To make your writing clearer, use these tips:
Avoid overly long sentences and paragraphs.
Repeat important words to avoid misunderstanding.
Don't describe more than one action in a sentence unless writing about strictly related actions.
Use words such as "and," "then," "but," "a," "the," "this," and "that" to make your message clear.

You can make your text easier to understand by using certain grammatical forms. To make your writing clearer, follow these rules:
Express actions with verbs, not nouns.
Use active voice.
Split clusters of nouns into smaller logical units.

section.p: Search your text for unintended linebreaks and punctuation marks (such as periods in place of commas). CAT (computer-assisted translation) tools may misinterpret such characters and split sentences into separate units. This can lead to translation errors and inconsistencies.
Avoid using pagebreaks and empty lines to layout your document. The same content can have a different volume in different languages.
section.div: Important: When localizing a DITA project, always send the translators your source files rather than the output (such as PDF or HTML files).

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.
a.title: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.
a.title: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.

div.p: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.

section.div:
When you plan the localization of your project, it is important to identify content that should be left untranslated. Here are a few examples of such content:
proper names, such as brand names
contact details
code blocks
UI text (if the UI is not localized)
legal text (may need to be handled separately)
Tip: You can use glossaries (on page ) to identify content that must be left untranslated.

section.p: If your project contains references to UI text, it is important to consider whether the UI is translated and if so, into which languages. If the UI is not localized, you should instruct translators on how they should approach UI text. For example, you may want them to provide a translation in brackets.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to prepare your DITA code for localization using the xml:lang and translate attributes.
a.title: Learn how to prepare your DITA code for localization using the xml:lang and translate attributes.

li.a: Preparing DITA code for localization (on page )

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.
a.title: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.
a.title: Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.

div.p: Learn the benefits of using glossaries in your localization process.

section.p: Glossaries are the easiest way to improve consistency of translated text. Different translators (or even the same translator at different times) can translate the same term in various ways. Giving them a glossary of approved translations can increase the consistency of terminology in one project or different projects concerning the same product.
section.div: Note: Most CAT tools enable automatic terminology checks to ensure a translator has used terms from the glossary. Although such checks are less useful in languages in which the same word can have various grammatical forms .

section.p: Glossaries can also specify text that should not be translated, such as brand names.

If you don't want a given term to be tarnslated in a particular way, a glossary is also a good place to specify that. For example, the word "pacemaker" can be translated into Polish as "rozrusznik", but you may want translators to use the less colloquial "stymulator" instead.
Glossaries can also provide context for each term, such as its definition.

Glossaries (called term bases) can be developed directly in a CAT tool. Most CAT tools have their own term base format, but you can use a universal format called TermBase eXchange (TBX) to exchange term bases between different tools.
You can also prepare a glossary as a CSV (Comma-Separated Values) file in a spreadsheet editor and then import it into a CAT tool.

figcaption.span: A simple bilingual glossary developed in a spreadsheet editor

img.alt: A simple bilingual glossary developed in a spreadsheet editor
img.css:oxy-alt-text: A simple bilingual glossary developed in a spreadsheet editor

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.
a.title: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.

div.p: Learn a few tips to make images in your project easier to localize.

section.p: If your images contain text that needs to be localized, avoid using bitmaps, such as JPG or PNG files. Instead, use SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) files. Most CAT tools can translate text contained in SVG files.
To simplify the localization process, avoid using descriptions within images. Instead, use numbered callouts and explain them under the image.SS

img.alt: A 'fig' DITA element containing an image with two callouts that are explained in a numbered list below the image
img.css:oxy-alt-text: A 'fig' DITA element containing an image with two callouts that are explained in a numbered list below the image

section.p: If your documentation contains user interface (UI) screens, it is important to consider whether the UI is going to be localized. You may need to plan for additional steps to prepare UI screens in target languages.

a.title: Learn a few tips to make your text easier to translate and less likely to cause translation errors.

div.p: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.

section.div:
A logical folder structure will make localization easier. Do not keep all your files in one folder. Instead, create separate folders for your topics, images, and other content.
Tip: To avoid publishing problems, always store your DITA maps at a level above your topics and images.

It is common practice to prefix topic names with "c_", "t_", "r_," and "_g" for concepts, tasks, references, and glossary entries, respectively. For example:
c_magic_wand.dita
t_how_to_cast_a_spell.dita
r_wand_specifications.dita
g_wand_shaft.dita
section.p: For larger projects, it may be useful to create separate folders for topics of each type (that is concepts, tasks, references, and glossary entries). This will make managing the project easier.

img.alt: A flow chart depicting basic project structure with separe folders for images and each type of topics
img.css:oxy-alt-text: A flow chart depicting basic project structure with separe folders for images and each type of topics

section.p: To make the localization process easier, create a separate subfolder for each language version. Each subfolder should have the same structure.

img.alt: A flow chart depicting project structure divided into separe folders for different language versions
img.css:oxy-alt-text: A flow chart depicting project structure divided into separe folders for different language versions

section.p: Some files, such as images and other content, will be shared among language versions. They don't need to be translated. It's a good idea to keep files you don't want to translate in a separate folder.

img.alt: A flow chart depicting project structure divided into separe folders for different language versions and a common folder for untranslated files
img.css:oxy-alt-text: A flow chart depicting project structure divided into separe folders for different language versions and a common folder for untranslated files

div.p: Learn how to prepare your DITA code for localization using the xml:lang and translate attributes.

section.h3: Setting the language of topics and maps
section.div: It is a best practice to specify the language of your DITA files, even if you are not planning localization at the moment. To specify the language and country of a topic or map, set the xml:lang attribute of its root element: <concept id="c_magic_tricks_vs_the_real_thing" xml:lang="en-US">
Tip: To set an attribute of an element in oXygen XML Editor, select the element, press Alt + Enter, and type the name of the attribute you want to set.

section.h3: Identifying content not to be translated
section.div: To identify a fragment that must not be translated, set the translate attribute to ""no": <codeblock id="codeblock_spells" translate="no"> let spellsLeft = 7; </codeblock>

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.
a.title: Learn about types of content that you may wish to leave untranslated.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to adjust text sorting using the sort-as and index-sort-as elements and change text direction using the dir element.
a.title: Learn how to adjust text sorting using the sort-as and index-sort-as elements and change text direction using the dir element.

div.p: Learn how to adjust text sorting using the sort-as and index-sort-as elements and change text direction using the dir element.

section.h3: Sorting text using the sort-as element
section.p: In languages like English you can easily sort lists by alphabetical order. But text in languages such as Japanese and Chinese cannot be always sorted that way. This is because the same character can have different pronunciations depending on the meaning.
section.div: To specify text that will be used for sorting, add a sort-as element inside a sorted element: <glossentry id="gloss-harry-potter"> <glossterm>ハリー・ポッター</glossterm> <prolog> <sort-as>Harry Potter</sort-as> </prolog> <glossdef></glossdef> </glossentry>

section.h3: Sorting index terms using the index-sort-as element
section.div: Similarly, you can adjust the storting order of index terms by adding the index-sort-as element: <indexterm>ハリー・ポッター <index-sort-as>Harry Potter</index-sort-as> </indexterm>

section.h3: Changing text direction using the dir element
section.div: English and many other languages use left-to-right (LTR) script. But there are many languages like Hebrew or Arabic that use right-to-left (RTL). To optimize localization, it's a best practice to specify text direction using the dir attribute: <map xml:lang="ar-IQ" dir ="rtl">
Tip: To set an attribute of an element in oXygen XML Editor, select the element, press Alt + Enter, and type the name of the attribute you want to set.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to prepare your DITA code for localization using the xml:lang and translate attributes.
a.title: Learn how to prepare your DITA code for localization using the xml:lang and translate attributes.

li.a: Preparing DITA code for localization (on page )

div.p: Learn about best practices of reusing content with conrefs and keyrefs to avoid problems with localization.

section.div: DITA lets you easily reuse content using the conref attribute.Figure 2. Example of content referencing in DITA
Tip: To set an attribute of an element in oXygen XML Editor, select the element, press Alt + Enter, and type the name of the attribute you want to set.

Improper use of content referencing can lead to translation errors (such as wrong gramamtical forms or text not matching the context). To avoid such errors, follow these rules:
Don't use conrefs for incomplete phrases. Instead, use them to reference whole sentences or larger fragments.
Avoid excessive content reuse. This may make it harder for translators to know the context of translated text.
Keyrefs can be used for standard text or expressions that can change, such as product names.Figure 3. Example of keyword referencing in DITA

When used improperly, keyrefs can lead to translation errors. You can avoid them by following these tips:
Use keyrefs for non-declinable terms, such as product names or UI terms.
Avoid using keyrefs for common nouns.
Treat keyrefs as proper nouns and don't precede them with articles.
Tip: To avoid translation errors, it may be a good idea to resolve all conrefs and keyrefs (on page ) before localizing your project.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to quickly replace content references and key references with content in oXygen XML Editor.
a.title: Learn how to quickly replace content references and key references with content in oXygen XML Editor.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.
a.title: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.

div.p: Learn how to quickly replace content references and key references with content in oXygen XML Editor.
div.section: When preparing your project for localization, it may be useful to replace content references (conrefs) and key references (keyrefs) with appropriate content. To resolve all conrefs and keyrefs in a topic in oXygen XML Editor, follow these steps:

li.span: Open a topic containing references and switch to the Author mode.
Go to DITA > Replace All References with Content.

img.alt: 'DITA' menu in oXygen with the 'Replace All References with Content' option
img.css:oxy-alt-text: 'DITA' menu in oXygen with the 'Replace All References with Content' option

div.section: All references in the topic are replaced with relevant content.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn about best practices of reusing content with conrefs and keyrefs to avoid problems with localization.
a.title: Learn about best practices of reusing content with conrefs and keyrefs to avoid problems with localization.

h2.span: Importing a DITA project into memoQ

div.p: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.

section.p: When translating a DITA project, it is important to preserve the relationships between files. To import your project into memoQ without losing the project's folder strucure, follow these steps:

li.span: Go to Project > New Project > New Project.
In the New memoQ project dialog, enter the Name of the project.

img.alt: Choosing a language pair in 'New memoQ project' dialog
img.css:oxy-alt-text: Choosing a language pair in 'New memoQ project' dialog

li.span: Enter the Client and any optional details, then click Next.
In the Translation memories step, choose or create a translation memory.
In the Term bases step, choose or create a term base.
Go to Documents > Import > Import Folder Structure.
Click … next to the Base path field, choose the folder where your project is located, and click OK.

img.alt: The 'Add folder structure' dialog in memoQ
img.css:oxy-alt-text: The 'Add folder structure' dialog in memoQ

li.span: In the Document import options dialog, remove any files you don't want to translate.

img.alt: The 'Document import options' dialog in memoQ
img.css:oxy-alt-text: The 'Document import options' dialog in memoQ

div.section:
Project files are ready for translation.
Tip: To export a translated project, right-click on the root folder and choose Export > Export (Stored Path).

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.
a.title: Learn how to organize your project to make localization easier.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.
a.title: Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.

div.p: Learn how to simplify your translation process in memoQ by creating a view containing only repetitions.
div.section: If your DITA project contains a lot of repetitive content, it may be useful to include all repetitions in one view. In order to create a view containing all repetitions in memoQ, follow these steps:

li.span: Go to Project home > Translations and select all files.
Right-click the files and choose Create View.

img.alt: The 'Create View' option in memoQ 'Translations' screen
img.css:oxy-alt-text: The 'Create View' option in memoQ 'Translations' screen

li.span: In the Create view dialog, enter the Name of the view, select Extract repetitions, and click OK.

div.section: You can work on a view containing all repeating segments in your project.

a.css:oxy-alt-text: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.
a.title: Learn how to import your DITA project into memoQ while preserving the project's folder structure.
